job_title: IS Analyst in New Orleans, LA
pros: 401k match, vested after a few years
cons:
From constant upgrades, Go-lives, Saturday work information services was one of the worst Departments to work for at Ochsner Health. Ochsner is known for their low 'non-profit' salaries but Information Services pays better than the other departments. If you try to leave to go to another department you will get about a $20,000 pay cut. 

Upper management didn't trust anyone to work from home pre-pandemic and forced everyone to keep their cameras on during the pandemic. It took a pandemic for some leaders (supervisors/Managers) to even pay attention to their employees.

The toxic culture of Information Services is a red flag for anyone trying to join. It's all about who you are friends with and not your actual skill set. Now, analysts who haven’t even been there for 3-4 years are making more than a musts who have been there for 8-10 years.

review_title: Beware of Micro-Managers & Toxic Work Environment
job_title: Marketing Manager in New Orleans, LA
pros:
C-Level Executives are amazing
Work from home flexibility
cons:
Lower level managers have little experience, and very little awareness of how their employees behave towards new people behind closed doors. 

There is little to no onboarding or training. Everyone tells you it’s a sink or swim environment. So if you come from a small company, there is a giant learning curve that you won’t be prepared for, and they won’t help you overcome. 

If you me 30 day performance review is poor and you’re blindsided, this is typical, there will be no action plan from your Senior or Manager or accountability for their role in getting you up to speed or to get you on track and zero support to help you succeed.

Senior employees let their personal opinions and feelings about you get in the way of a professional work day. If they don’t like you, you are going to fail from lack of support, training, and overall harsh judgement of your work. 

I’ve never been so micromanaged in my life, to the point where I did not even write my own emails to people in the company. The senior to my role wrote them for me.

Zero respect or understanding for neuro-diverse employees and different types of communication styles. As a high functioning person with Autism, the treatment and berating I received from the Senior to my position was hostile and embarrassing. Her opinion of me as a person clouded our professional relationship to the point where I would be engaging in small talk and making jokes with upper management, and they took a harmless laugh about my struggles with my Microsoft Calendar, and they brought me in our mutual managers office to talk about how I embarrassed them and make an inappropriate comment about not knowing how to do my job. Which was frankly a lie or a giant misunderstanding on their part due to their bias against me. 

I’ve been in therapy for two years now, going through the verbal and emotional abuse that affected me during my 4 months at this job. Make sure to get out your managers style of management.

job_title: Physician in Baton Rouge, LA
pros: Good benefits and vacation package; had to negotiate salary but did arrive at a good number--initial offer was very low. The company talks a good talk when it comes to acceptance, tolerance, diversity, lack of prejudice, and concern about physician wellbeing and burnout, but does not consistently deliver on their goals.
cons: I never considered leaving medicine completely until I worked for this company. I think for physicians who are happy to show up, do as they're told, get by with limited resources (particularly in the way of support staff), and have little to no autonomy in exchange for a steady paycheck and benefits, Ochsner works. For those who are less motivated by money, are free-thinking, want more control over their practice and autonomy in how it is run, or expect the best for themselves and their patients, this employer is not a good fit.

review_title: good company investing in the future, pity about the default hierarchy that creates negativity in the environment
job_title: Clinical Pharmacist in Baton Rouge, LA
pros:
Competitive salary and benefits for the area/state
Ochsner actively promotes individual career development, surprised at the limited employee turnover even in the less well paid positions considering how high turnover can often be in healthcare
Good community involvement/presence
Investing in future healthcare directions
Willing to give employees a lot of autonomy and ownership of different projects
cons:
Generally salaries in this area are deflated compared to salaries across the rest of the US, despite not having significant differences in costs of living when operating in Ochsner
Takes 6 years to be fully vested in retirement benefits
Health plan is ok, but not amazing compared to other places I've worked
Incredible amount of heirarchical reinforcement with anyone who isn't a provider (i.e. MD or NP/PA) being treated like a second class citizen (MDs get visibly better treatment for needs everyone has day-to-day - including preferential parking spots, better time off and retirement benefits, CE support at 10k per year while there's no policy for any other department to get CE support despite many having clinical professional requirements as well, free food from the cafeteria (they can literally walk past MAs, nurses, housekeeping staff and other workers paid at low end of the pay scale, and not pay, while other staff with lower incomes pay out of their own pocket in front of them). While it doesn't affect the quality of the job benefits provided, it creates a negative association and cliquey-ness that can be detrimental within a department.

job_title: Coordinator in New Orleans, LA
pros: The people you meet are very friendly, willing to help you with whatever you need, and very involved. When you hold meetings, people are typically actually listening and very engaged in the discussion. Honestly one of the best work environments I’ve had in many many years. My department is very supportive of each other and everyone helps each other out. Company wise, the GPT accrual for new employees isn’t bad at all. You get one personal day that’s separate from the rest of your time. Lots of perks with special discounts for being an employee, a decent list of paid holidays, and some people get annual raises based on performance evaluations
cons: Depending on which location you’re at, the culture is very different. The good things I have to say about Baptist specifically aren’t going to apply to Ochsner as a System. Sometimes work life balance is hard to maintain. You’re constantly getting emails in your inbox, zoom calls, and other things you need to balance and it’s easy to lose track.

job_title: Plant Operator in Baton Rouge, LA
pros: Job is recession proof-ish. They can be understanding at times. You'll get your 40 hours a week, and the supervisor has improved in a few ways over the past few years. It can feel like a family, although that makes getting messed over that much worse.
cons:
It's alright. Could be better could be worse. Expect low raises and to hear "we'll look into that" 24/7. Your job title will be changed every year or two so they don't have to increase your pay, and you'll be given tons of out-of-scope work with absolutely no pay increase. Also, half the team is too old for about 80% of the work so a lot of it will be offloaded on you. And the supervisor has conflict-resolution issues, although he's gotten a bit better in the past few years. We as a team have even contacted HR before with a list of issues and concerns and -almost- nothing was ever done or brought to fruition. 

Ochsner is plenty big enough to pay their employees well. Stop hiring new people when you're handing out 1 - 2% raises as if it's impressive.

pros:
I work in a corporate area and the people that I have been able to work with are extremely down to earth, smart, and genuinely want employees at all levels to succeed.  One of Ochsner's core values is "patients first" and I truly believe that most employees keep this in mind, even if they are not directly patient facing.  
There are a lot of opportunities for leadership development and further education, which I believe is so important.
cons: Everyone at Ochsner talks about how bad the pay is--and this is true!  They spend a LOT of money on agency/contract help in many departments (nurses, therapists, medical coders, etc.).  Although fair market value in the south may be lower than most of the nation, Ochsner should consider that they are headquartered in New Orleans, and the pay here should be more competitive with other cities around the nation.

cons: If you ask any employee at Ochsner their number one complaint it would be pay. Ochsner is the lowest paying hospital in the region. We do a huge amount of work, and have a huge workload for the ever growing footprint of clinics and hospitals that Ochsner continues to take on, but yet our pay does not change or increase. We are expected to do much more work with the same and sometimes less people to do it with.

job_title: Emergency Department Technician in Gretna, LA
pros: Cutting edge company, lots of training opportunities, company seems to care in the big picture, amazing facilities, smooth onboarding process, most of the employees are absolutely fantastic! Some of the best coworkers ever. LOVE the CEO and company culture.
cons:
Through the entirety of my employment, my leadership was distant, uninvolved, and frankly, uncaring. However, things ultimately came to a head when my pleas for assistance and guidance through COVID were ignored. 

When local schools shut down leaving my four kids without childcare, I felt like I had no choice but to give immediate notice of termination. I was overwhelmed, as everyone is in this time, to say the very least. I respectfully and repeatedly requested that an exception be made so I would be marked as "eligible for re-hire" to return as soon as possible, but my requests were ignored.

I sent many, many follow-up emails to lower leadership, and then eventually upper leadership, all of which were ignored by everyone. 

Needless to say, I don't feel that I was taken care of in a time of need. The company is absolutely cutting edge and has so many amazing opportunities for employees, but my experience really missed the mark because of very poor leadership.

pros: Worked at Ochsner Kenner less than one year in the OR. The manager is nice and fair. Not very much good to say.  Most of the other nurses were decent and supportive.
cons: The surgeons are verbally abusive to say the least!  I had never been cursed at while working as a Registered Nurse in my entire life until I worked there.  And not just once, multiple times. Even the residents go on power trips (excuse me, but you're a resident!!!). I'm making a quarter of my salary more at my new job with better hours. The pay rate is out of date at Ochsner and my friend recently quit. She's making more money, too. They pay less because they own almost every hospital in the New Orleans area. That's why they have to offer bonuses for people to stay. Needless  to say, they could keep my $2000. I didn't want to spend another minute there. And for owning most of the city,  they could really offer better benefits. They also expect you to make your job your #1 priority in life and act like the position you've been given is the be all end all. Newsflash: not for someone with experience...

job_title: Marketing in New Orleans, LA
pros: The team seemed amazing. The pay was great!
cons: They preach work-life-balance, but between all of the meetings each day there was little time for a break. Instead of having documented processes and systems in place the training was a 30 minute run around from one cubicle to another taking notes. When I asked if they had a list of vendors they said, "You'll have to figure it out on your own." Each person emailed me different vendors and contacts and forwarded me existing emails to try to learn things from. It was chaotic and not organized at all. I would receive hundreds of emails each day instead of someone just sending me a phone call or Skyping me for a quick question. Because everyone's inbox was full I could never get answers on anything. I would have to plan a project two months out because of the turnaround time on response. They are growing faster than they can keep up with.

job_title: Staff RN in New Orleans, LA
pros: I enjoy my actual department, endoscopy. I have been with the ochsner main campus for 6.5 years. Overall, I enjoy my pay and being able to be a level 3 clinical ladder. many positions overall in main to move throughout the system .
cons: no employee satisfaction , work life balance. Parking is a nightmare. There is no incentive to be health conscious and walk , because it is a mostly uncovered, unsecure walk in the heat and rain. the only alternative is taking buses, that drive and text, and make people late for work. There is no daycare incentive for families with kids. Absence policy is very strict , as a parking tickets. There is less system positive rewards. Should be the parking garage higher so that all employees can park there.

job_title: Research Administrator in New Orleans, LA
pros:
Direct manager is superb!  No micromanagement, flexible schedule, trusts employees in the office.

Benefits such as PTO, insurance and retirement contributions seem good.
cons:
Research Admin is a mess from top to bottom.  It feels like Research is an afterthought rather than a part of the overall system (it's been like this for years, but the promises that this will improve have never materialized).  Leadership has a poor understanding of the fundamentals of clinical research and the necessary infrastructure.  Accountability and communication are not valued by the leadership.  It is rumored that the Research department has the highest turnover in all of the system, which would not be surprising.

No room for advancement, "it's too difficult to justify to HR"

review_title: Poor management, more worried about keeping staffing down to save money.

pros: The Therapist are some of the finest I have ever worked with.  With that in mind, the burn out rate is extremely high with contract Therapist not renewing contracts and turning down offers for full time positions.
cons:
Some members of management don’t like having to work with Therapist who are older than they are.  When you add more experienced than they are, you get open hostility where you are told that you are to old to keep up with the work load and should find a position somewhere else).

The work assignment’s are made with unreasonable expectations (you’re assigned patients on different floors in different wings of the hospital.  You are also expected to do O2 rounds on the other patients on each of your floors, this means you are expected to see roughly 50 patients on each floor on top of the 16 to 18 treatments you are assigned and expected to do in a two hour time frame).

review_title: I have been working for Ochsner for a short time, but am already blown away by how great of an organization it is.
job_title: Senior Recruiter in New Orleans, LA
pros: They have a seamless and efficient on boarding process and everyone in every department is incredibly welcoming to new hires. They truly care about their employees and do a great job to keep employees’ wellbeing in mind when making executive decisions. Ochsner management also has a keen eye for recognizing talent and making sure your skills best align with the position you are in and the projects you are working on.
cons: There are definitely changes in the organization (something past/present employees seem to comment on often), but from my experience, all changes are implemented strategically to better align their business practices with changing markets, employee feedback, and ways to keep Ochsner operating as efficiently as possible. I would be concerned if I were working for a stagnant company which has operated the same way for years and years and appreciate that Ochsner is constantly trying to improve.

job_title: Registered Nurse in New Orleans, LA
pros: It is a financially stable hospital system.  They promote education and betterment of the staff.
cons: Extremely top heavy with leaders.  Lot's of kiss butt favoritism- "do as I say, not as I do".  Communication disconnect from top management to worker bees.  Way to large and they keep expanding which make compliance difficult.  Not proactive and thought out when they implement projects- not enough planning involved so you end up doing the same project 2 or 3 times- very inefficient.  Poor onboarding of new staff leads to high turnover.

job_title: Registered Nurse in New Orleans, LA
pros:
I started my nursing career at Ochsner in February 2016. I had an amazing trainer who not only instilled in me the knowledge of the job but she also brought out the confindence in myself. The team of nurses I work with are like family. We have tough days but we help each other out to get through it.  Ultimately we work together for the best interest for our patients. 

Not only am I an employee, but I am also a patient. I know Ochsner is the place to go when I am ill. To this day, I see doctors and nurses in the halls that have taken care of me and my family members and they remember me! Ochsner employees take the time to take care of the patient not just their diseases.
cons: There are days we are short staffed and patient safety goes out the window.

review_title: Great Health Care provider, lousy employer

pros: My co-workers were great and the vacation time was a little better than average however, there was never real time off of work.  Great ideas, but poor execution of those ideas.
cons: The pay was below average for the amount of work. Also, one person does the job of 2 or 3 because the department runs on a budget that does not allow for incentives nor raises over 25cents a year. That is an insult. I resolve this in my mind because I am in school working towards a degree but most people here are not. They still deserve better pay as do I.

job_title: Talent Acquisition in New Orleans, LA
pros:
- Great Culture centered around teamwork
- I learn every single day. I am surrounded by subject matter experts who constantly share best practices and drive growth and innovation. 
-Opportunities to work on projects that match your interest. This really allows further development of your skill set. 
- Executive team visibility. The executive team is present and interactive. They truly do listen, and often allow employee creativity to drive initiatives and improvement. 
- Career advancement. Honestly, the opportunities for growth are limitless.
cons:
Driving innovation and finding top talent is not easy. You have to be creative, work hard, and sacrifice. 
There are days when the work week is extended. However, I do honestly feel appreciated and my hard work has always been acknowledged.

review_title: If Oschsner lived by the rules it espoused it would be fantastic!
job_title: Registered Nurse in New Orleans, LA
pros: If you are in the "In crowd," and are willing to turn a blind eye to flagrant abuse of position and power, then Ochsner Medical Center in New Orleans, has a place for you! The salaries are good by industry standards.
cons: If you are different, or perceived as so, you are a threat to this organization. They do not value people who have original, innovative, or new ideas, but are threatened by them.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Orleans, LA
pros: Being a nurse at Ochsner allowed me to develop clinically as well as grow my leadership skills.  I was a supervisor in two years, and then a manager in four.  At Ochsner, you can be a hospital bedside nurse and enjoy your work, or you can move into case management, leadership, research, clinic positions, performance improvement etc.  You can move from busy and varied med/surg to the best, most acute, critical care areas in the region! You can be in acute psyche, post acute care, home health.. all without leaving the company!  You will also meet people and form relationships that will follow you throughout your career.  The people here are what makes coming to work worth it.
cons: Parking at Jefferson Highway is a bear.  You have to be here 15 minutes before your shift start time in order to be on time.

review_title: Great opportunity for professional experience but organization culture is not caring towards employees.
job_title: 1-3% Annual Bonus Depending On Performance Rating in New Orleans, LA

Culture-wise, organization rewards/promotes people who are self-serving and overly competitive.  Culture is very hierarchical.  Management skill is disappointingly low.  Managers don't communicate meaningfully with employees or show that they really value their teams.  There is more lip service than support given to employees.

job_title: Medical Assistant in New Orleans, LA

cons: The pay is horrible. Annual raises are a joke. It sad that when you estimate that your pay in the next 5 years will only be about 60 cents more than what im paid now. I dont think that the company values their employees enough to pay them what they are worth. But its a wonderful ace to get the experience you need and leave.

review_title: Why I love working at Ochsner
job_title: RN Nurse Supervisor in New Orleans, LA

Your growth and level of exposure to education and opportunities are endless. Every day is a different day at work and even though I’m not a morning person, I look forward to coming to work. I love our Providers, my team and my coworkers. If you are looking for s great place to work. Look no further. You have found us!

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Baton Rouge, LA

Systems and infrastructure (like clean parking lots and lobbies) get ignored.    The work-life balance myth is a joke and a lie for non-clinic staff.  The expectation was that I was always on call, regardless, no exceptions, just get over it.

Construction of new facilities

Everything constantly changing, special rules for special people connected to Ochsner Higher Management.  Same position, different title in different department has different pay scale.  Newer employees get paid more in same position than older more experienced employees.

review_title: Horrible place to work that doesn’t care about the people they take care of or employ.

There’s not much good to be said about the place.

review_title: A great place with a horrible culture.

review_title: Ochsner has its ups and its downs.

review_title: OHS is a very innovative Healthcare System.

review_title: This employer removes negative reviews, beware!

cons: Unable to do my job with provided equipment/login information for the computer.  Worked for the company for nearly 6 months without being able to do my job.  Was told many lies (incorrect information) upon being hired (my fault for not asking for this in writing) such as access to 401K, work schedule, work location, work hours and pay increase schedule.  I was yelled at on multiple occasions by doctors for being in the wrong place trying to do my job...since I couldn't access the correct program myself.  My hours were reduced because I did not work off the clock.  If you don't work off the clock on days clinic runs late, you'll be scheduled for one day less every week following.

job_title: Patient Access Representative in Kenner, LA

Very much favoritism shown by supervisors and rules not uniformally  enforced across the board. CONSTANTLY moving from place to place within the department but having new tasks and assignments and not enough given  to totally learn the new job. Biggest problem was with managers who were not trained properly to be a manager, shared personal information that should have been protected,gossiping, and who routinely corrected/criticised in front of other employees.

review_title: NOT THE PLACE IT USED TO BE---And too bad
job_title: Medical Professional in New Orleans, LA
pros: Probably the most high tech medical center in the area.  Will accept patients with the most serious medical issues.  Great place to gain experience in some departments.  The organization has expanded across the region possibly offering transfer positions to other affiliated centers
cons: Too many to say in one paragraph unfortunately.  Where the institution was once an enviable place to work and more than often in the Best Places To Work in the area, they have LOST this distinction in both polling and in my personal opinions.  Their decision to accept a GE model for taking care of patients has caused an impersonal patient experience, disgruntled employee attitude with low morale, and an unhealthy exodus of some of their most valued and experienced clinicians often due to unscrupulous management decisions with deceitful accusations.  Interestingly, many employees that have been trouble makers for years are maintained at a lower pay range, surprise surprise.  Furthermore, management continues to change often and a lack of consistent policies are apparent even angering the employee more so.   The ship is sinking as management with MBA's slap themselves on the back for saving money while employees are often overworked an remain under paid relative to other centers in the area.

job_title: Staff RN/Relief CN in New Orleans, LA
pros: Great place for new grads to get experience. I gained a wealth of knowledge and skills that prepared me for any job in the future.  Education for nurses is encouraged  and supported.
cons: The pay was not up to par with other local hospitals. Nursing staff was over worked and unappreciated.  Large amount of turnover of staff and very little ancillary staff to back up nursing. I worked under 6 different unit managers in a 3 year time span.

review_title: The people are nice to work with, but responsible hard workers risk being taken advantage of.
job_title: in New Orleans, LA
pros: Great stable employer, good benefits, nice people
cons: employee salaries are below market, especially given the hours of work that are expected (except for the very highest executives); Raises that are anything more than a cost-of-living adjustment are rare, except at the executive level. Even though work-life balance is verbally encouraged, work-life balance is only really acceptable for low-level employees.

review_title: Low compensation has taken a toll on employees as far as loyalty, dedication, morale, performance and productivity.
job_title: Non-Clinical/Administrative in New Orleans, LA
pros: Nice, fun co-workers, like we were in it  together.  Good amount of training when hired.  If you are especially social and make an effort to connect with the "right people," you could possibly be promoted.  Team pulls together during hurricanes and emergency events. Good orientation and onboarding training, although not consistent in all departments. Very rewarding to have an impact on patients and their families.  Great medical staff with good outcomes.  Innovative medical procedures.
cons:
My compensation was in the 50 percentile, making half of  the metro N.O.  standard wage for that position with my education and skill set. Many of middle management weren't  true leaders, or they were too intimidated by upper management to speak their minds and take charge.  They followed orders and parroted talking points rather than being innovative, pro-active and solving issues. Many didn't  stand up for their exemplary employees when it was needed.  "Yes men" or employees who had an inside track appeared to be the ones considered for leadership positions.  Working hard and doing a good job was not enough to merit advancement.  Mind you, I didn't strive for advancement, so my opinion is based on observation and speaking with other employees.  It's a big topic of conversation there.
Salary was not a living wage.   It would greatly benefit Ochsner to invest in their employees.  Many hourly employees lacked motivation and had decreased productivity due to low wages and perceived lack of opportunity for advancement.  Must be self motivated to consistently perform at peak level.   Very small awards were given to employees recognized for best performance of the quarter, etc. A company the size of Ochsner should award more, perhaps paid days off so as not to incur actual costs.
The e-mails sent from CEO seemed like it was just talk, not that he actually believed it.  It's easy to put out some talking points, but unless they're honest and acted upon, it's just repetitive words.  CEO and all upper management should take time to visit the front lines, much valuable insight and feedback could be gained while interacting with the hourly employees.  Skip the Power of One presentations and use that time to interact with front line employees.  Empower employees at all levels.  I think you'll be surprised how they will meet and exceed your expectations.  
Ochsner is a good place to gain experience and training that can be leveraged to seek better employment.  I believe my employment at Ochsner gave me an edge when seeking new employment.  Potential employers seemed to value and possibly respect my association with Ochsner.  Good for resume.  
Bottom Line:  If you can live on what they pay you, it's a good place to get your feet wet. Be assertive in asking for what you want from your supervisors. Hopefully top management will wise up, understand the actual value of their employees and become a true leader in healthcare.

job_title: Medical Assistant in New Orleans, LA

review_title: Long Term but for how long?
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Orleans, LA

review_title: Needs an overhaul of structure in the IS department
job_title: Senior Analyst in New Orleans, LA
pros:
-Job stability is top-notch.
-Micro-management is not very prevalent.
-Lots of good people with very good intentions.
-Work is rewarding even though not on the front-lines of patient care.
cons:
-Some of the management has been around so long that they can not be gotten rid of even though they are not up to speed with today's technologies to stay relevant.
-Training is a joke (Internal training on bland subjects does not better anyone's career.  Send IT workers to IT certification courses so they can learn "hard" skills vice "soft" skills).
-CIO has no technical background, only working with Electronic Medical Record (EMR) system (EPIC) and therefore only sees EMR workers as worthwhile to the organization (Lean more on CTO for this in the future).

-Annual raises are a joke even for employees with reviews that show stellar performance.

-Disagreement with managers, even when done respectfully, will black list you from advancement (even if you are arguing to help potentially save patients' lives).
-Lack of communication when new deployments are going on is downright embarrassing, causing IT people to jump through hoops to meet last minute deadlines.

review_title: Buyer Beware- A Sad Cycle in Ochsner History
job_title: in New Orleans, LA
pros: Young graduates can get clinical experience with fairly high tech equipment and an above average acuity of patient.  Discount membership to their fitness center.  Main campus continues to be slowly renovated improving the aesthetics of what clientele and patients see.  Expansion from a stand alone hospital to a system that may compete with other systems in the South East.
cons: Sadly, Ochsner was once the BEST place to work in New Orleans and probably top of the heap relative to most hospitals in the country.  Those times are GONE as the current administration has completely destroyed the trusting atmosphere and lowered morale beyond anything that I had ever seen.  The corporate structure modeled after a GE paradigm does not work and the "suits" have no clue what it takes to maintain a satisfied employee base which contributes to quality care.  Employees have been leaving in droves as Upper Management  refuses to listen to its employees suggestions and in stead, pays million of dollar to outside consultant that know little about the cultural area.  Ochsner has become it worst enemy and I see no recovery for a number of years and only when this set of administrators are eliminated.  And even then, a return to a more pleasant and enjoyable working atmosphere will take more time to win the trust back from employees.  DO NOT TRUST the HR department, as they are just a voice box for upper management, and continually change leadership striving to improve their negative image.  Spending way too much money on rah rah sessions rather than putting the money to work by maintaining employees.  So bad, they management have resorted to "creative" alternative methods to find new talent but unfortunately, new hires generally do not stay long due to the above mentioned issues.

review_title: The WORST Place for Nurses in NOLA
job_title: Registered Nurse in New Orleans, LA
pros: Lots of job openings, fairly easy to get hired. Good technology, emphasis on continuing education. Some of the units have been nicely renovated. Good tube system and EMR program.
cons: Ochsner is finding every way possible to abuse its nurses at the main campus location. The hospital pays significantly less than any other hospital in the area - including Touro, EJ, West Jeff and Tulane. When I switched jobs, my pay went up by more than 25% for the same full-time job from my new employer, a teaching hospital just a few miles away. Ochsner continues to add responsibilities to the nursing staff - most recently, the PCTs no longer do vitals or accuchecks so nurses now have to do that on top of managing patient loads that are at times unsafe. When the census is low, nurses get floated (without the option to refuse) to units they are untrained and unqualified for, and apparently now if you get called off, you will not be allowed to take vacation time to cover it. The hospital apparently dumps most of its budget into marketing and buying new locations instead of paying its staff a living wage and maintaining staffing levels at an appropriate level to ensure patient safety.I worried about losing my license due to the working conditions at main campus, and so did many of the nurses I worked with. In some departments, management has resorted to paying hiring bonuses to new grads in exchange for 2 year contracts - yet there is no retention bonus offered for RNs who stay in their job.  Bottom line, Ochsner is run like a for-profit corporation, not a world-class hospital.  They abuse their nurses, management is indifferent, and patients will eventually pay the price. With two new hospitals opening shortly, Ochsner needs to figure out how to retain its experienced staff before they all leave for the better pay and working conditions offered by the competition.

Very "top heavy" in leadership with strict hierarchy; you need permission to email anyone besides your immediate working team. Break protocol and you're reprimanded for disrespect.  Brand new supervisors are allowed to fire people on a whim without HRBP or upper management approval.  They are growing too fast for their own good. Avoid, avoid, avoid.

job_title: Therapy Services in New Orleans, LA
pros: great coworkers and good experience.
cons: VERY poor communication, beginning with the interview process. Unclear expectations and scheduling. So, to be clear FOR them: You DO work EVERY OTHER WEEKEND, BOTH SATURDAY AND SUNDAY, NOT just one of the days. The therapy position is HOURLY, NOT SALARY. You will be offered a yearly figure and they quickly break it down for you to hourly. You clock-in and clock-out upon arrival and departure and there is a half hour of UNPAID time allocation for lunch each day. The pay is signifcantly less than the starting pay listed on the APTA/AOTA websites. And don't worry, even though you are working every other weekend, you get a minimal increase in your hourly pay (< $4), it is in NO WAY closer to time and a half. Also, whether you plan your schedule to leave at 4 or 4:30, you will HAVE until 5 pm at least 1x per month to cover necessary patients.  You will be told that there will be an inital period of orientation and then after about a week you will see patients... also NOT true, you will be expected to pickup patients and start a caseload by the third day in the hospital and you will be expected to carry a FULL caseload after a week and a half. This may not be trouble for all, but just a warning for new graduates.  Also, on weekends, expect to work in an area of the hospital that you have never been oriented to, this is where having awesome co-workers come in handy because they are consistently willing to help, but management doesn't play a role AT ALL. Another thing to pay attention to is the "flex day" you have off when you have to work the next weekend. They say they offer flexibility and try to accomodate those that work every other weekend. This is NOT true, you do NOT get to pick your flex days. In fact, you can count on NEVER having two days off in a row when you work a weekday (i.e. work Mon, Tues, Wed, have off  Thursday, work Friday, Saturday Sunday, have off Monday and then work Tues-Fri and then have that weekend off and then repeat.)
